form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Q. & A. statement by MING LO CHIN ( (cont'd), In Re: MING LO CHIN, File A14 612 729

full_text: Screened by NARA, 8/18/2023 Q. & A. statement by MING LO CHIN (cont'd) In Re: MING LO CHIN. File A14 612 729 Q. How long do you intend to continue this employment? A. I don't know how long I would work for them and how long would be the period but if my children come to the United States and they can study and they can work, then if I am getting old, I certainly would retire. Q. If you are granted permanent residence in the United States, does your husband plan to join you? A. Certainly, since we have been separated for quite a few years. Q. Does your husband and your children plan to join you immediately if you are granted permanent residence in the Uni ed States? A. If it is possible, certainly. Q. Do you plan to continue this employment after your husband and children arrive in the United States? A. Morally speaking, a Chinese will not do things like that since the----since they helped me that way I would continue to work for them. Q. You previously stated that you came to the United States to visit a friend. What was your reason for remaining in the United States for such a prolreed period? Why did you not return to you family in Brazil? A. When I was in Brazil I heard people can get extension as long as two years. Since I arrived in the United States and since I have spend so much money I prefer to stay longer. Q. What was you reason for wanting to spend so much time in the United States? A. My children have been grown up and I have nothing to do at home, I mean in Brazil, so I spend the time as long as I can here. Q. During that period, How were you being supported in the United States? A. I brough with me some money and I live with my friend here. Q. How much money did you bring with you? A. Several hundred dollars U.S. money. Q. Could you be more specific. Exactly how much money did you bring with you? A. Six hundred dollars.
